llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "safe", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL response returns validation suggestions that reveal correct schema field names (e.g., \"title\", \"comments\"). This is an information disclosure issue (field_suggestions) because it helps an attacker discover the GraphQL schema and valid field names, making query enumeration and targeted probing easier. While this does not directly enable data exfiltration or injection, it leaks internal API structure and should be considered sensitive. Mitigation: disable verbose suggestion messages in production, return generic validation errors, or configure the GraphQL server to avoid exposing schema hints.", "evidence": "Error messages include suggestions: \"Field \\\"titel\\\" is not defined by type \\\"UpdatePostInput\\\". Did you mean \\\"title\\\"?\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"conteent\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\". Did you mean \\\"comments\\\"?\"", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "field_suggestions", "severity": "LOW", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Error messages include suggestions: \"Field \\\"titel\\\" is not defined by type \\\"UpdatePostInput\\\". Did you mean \\\"title\\\"?\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"conteent\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\". Did you mean \\\"comments\\\"?\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response returns validation suggestions that reveal correct schema field names (e.g., \"title\", \"comments\"). This is an information disclosure issue (field_suggestions) because it helps an attacker discover the GraphQL schema and valid field names, making query enumeration and targeted probing easier. While this does not directly enable data exfiltration or injection, it leaks internal API structure and should be considered sensitive. Mitigation: disable verbose suggestion messages in production, return generic validation errors, or configure the GraphQL server to avoid exposing schema hints."}}]

llm_results:
[{"detection_name": "LLM: html_injection", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response returns raw HTML in data fields (title and body). The body includes an inline event handler (onclick) that would execute JavaScript (fetch('/auth')) if inserted into a page using innerHTML or otherwise rendered as HTML. Because this value comes from an updatePost mutation, it is likely stored content that can lead to persistent (stored) HTML/DOM XSS when rendered unsafely in a browser. Impact includes arbitrary script execution in victims' browsers, data exfiltration (the fetch to /auth indicates potential to reach internal/auth endpoints), session theft, or actions performed on behalf of the user. Mitigations: treat these fields as untrusted, properly escape/encode output (render as textContent), sanitize allowed HTML on input using a whitelist-based sanitizer, disallow inline event handlers and javascript: URIs, and deploy a strict Content Security Policy to limit script execution.", "evidence": "Response contains HTML markup in returned fields: \"title\": \"
Injected
\", \"body\": \"\"", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "html_injection", "severity": "HIGH", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Response contains HTML markup in returned fields: \"title\": \"
Injected
\", \"body\": \"\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response returns raw HTML in data fields (title and body). The body includes an inline event handler (onclick) that would execute JavaScript (fetch('/auth')) if inserted into a page using innerHTML or otherwise rendered as HTML. Because this value comes from an updatePost mutation, it is likely stored content that can lead to persistent (stored) HTML/DOM XSS when rendered unsafely in a browser. Impact includes arbitrary script execution in victims' browsers, data exfiltration (the fetch to /auth indicates potential to reach internal/auth endpoints), session theft, or actions performed on behalf of the user. Mitigations: treat these fields as untrusted, properly escape/encode output (render as textContent), sanitize allowed HTML on input using a whitelist-based sanitizer, disallow inline event handlers and javascript: URIs, and deploy a strict Content Security Policy to limit script execution."}}]

simple_results: [{"detection_name": "Field Suggestions Enabled", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Information Disclosure", "description": "Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure", "evidence": "Found \"did you mean\" in error message - field suggestions are enabled"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "potential", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL error response includes an explicit suggestion of an existing field name (\"Did you mean 'title'?\"). This reveals schema information (valid field names on the Post type), enabling schema/field enumeration and making it easier for an attacker to craft valid queries. Although this does not directly return sensitive data, it is an information disclosure that can be leveraged to refine attacks against the API. Recommended mitigations: disable or remove field suggestion details in production error messages, return generic validation errors, suppress GraphQL suggestion text (depending on server implementation options), restrict or monitor introspection and query patterns, and apply rate limiting and authentication/authorization checks to limit abuse.", "evidence": "Error message: \"Cannot query field \\\"titel\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\". Did you mean \\\"title\\\"?\"", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "field_suggestions", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Error message: \"Cannot query field \\\"titel\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\". Did you mean \\\"title\\\"?\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL error response includes an explicit suggestion of an existing field name (\"Did you mean 'title'?\"). This reveals schema information (valid field names on the Post type), enabling schema/field enumeration and making it easier for an attacker to craft valid queries. Although this does not directly return sensitive data, it is an information disclosure that can be leveraged to refine attacks against the API. Recommended mitigations: disable or remove field suggestion details in production error messages, return generic validation errors, suppress GraphQL suggestion text (depending on server implementation options), restrict or monitor introspection and query patterns, and apply rate limiting and authentication/authorization checks to limit abuse."}}]
